moves.1. d4: In this game my opponent unleashed a surprising early piece sacrifice which had me worried, but thankfully I seemed to navigate the complications better than him!
moves.1... Nf6: So I head for an Indian set-up
moves.2. Nf3: He also develops his King's Knight
moves.2... g6: I prepare to fianchetto my bishop.
moves.3. Nc3: A little bit unusual, presumably hoping for 4. e4 and a Modern Defence set-up.
moves.3... d5: But I put a stop to that.
moves.6... g5: I attack again, slightly weakening my King-side position, but driving his bishop back
moves.7... Bf5: Played to prevent e2-e4 and with the idea of dropping back to g6 and covering some of the weak squares on my king-side.
moves.8. e3: So he plays it to e3 instead.
moves.8... Bg7: I at last finish the finachetto.
moves.9. Be5: He offers an exchange of bishops.
moves.9... f6: I block. I was expecting his bishop to roll back to g3 now, but instead he gave me a shock with.....(you may want to pause here and consider what other move white could possibly make?)
moves.10. Nh4: Now if I take the knight then he gets two pieces back - 10....gxh4 11. Qxh5+ and if 11...Kd7 he takes on f5 with check, or if I play Kf8 after Qxf5 my pawn on f6 is pinned. Fritz gives white an advantage of plus 1.81 here.
moves.10... Be6: After considering 10...0-0 and 10....Bxc2, Fritz finally comes up with this move - which I played. I was really worried about 11. Ng6 here, and Fritz agrees, it is the best move for white, and gives it as plus 1.5 to white.
moves.11... Qxc7: I take back. Fritz thinks that white is plus 1 now, but I was confident.
moves.12... Bf7: But now queen and knight are hanging.
moves.14. Ng6: The only way to save a piece.
moves.14... e6: Played to protect d5 and also to play f6-f5 if necessary.
moves.15. Bd3: This seems rather inconsistent. He seems to have allowed me to play Nc6 with gain of time.
moves.15... f5: Cutting off the protection of the knight.
moves.16. g4: Trying to save his knight. Fritz gives a small advantage to black now.
moves.16... Ne7: Fritz prefers 16....a6 as now white can play 17. Bb5+ and if 17.....Kd8 then 18. Nf4! saving the piece, as 18....Bxh5 then 19. Nxe6+ forking my king and queen. I was thinking that if Bb5+ I would have to play my knight back to c6, but after 17. h4! white is slightly better again.
moves.18. Qf3: Fritz agrees that this is best.
moves.19. Nxd5: He gets a second pawn for the piece.
moves.21. Bxf5: White gets, temporarily, a third pawn, but it is poisoned!
moves.22. Qd5+: White tries to break the pin.
moves.22... Bf7: I have to keep attacking, I don't want him castling, getting his king to safety and rooks into play.
moves.23. Qe4: He offers an exchange of queens.
moves.24. Kf1: This is another mistake, c3 was indicated.
moves.24... Rae8: Getting my last piece into play with tempo.. Black is 2 point up now, according to Fritz.
moves.25... Bg6: Dangerous pin on the bishop. Fritz actually like Be6 instead, but I didn't want him exchanging off this vulnerable bishop.
moves.27... Bc4+: Rather than repeat, I throw in a check.
moves.28. Kg2: King moves. Fritz here likes g5-g4 now.
moves.28... Qb5: This seemed good to me, threatening the bishop on f5 and also Bc4-d5
moves.30. Qh5: He attacks - maybe hoping for a perpetual check?
moves.30... Rxf5: Perhaps a bit speculative, but it worked out OK. Fritz prefers 30....Qc6 with plus 4 to black.
moves.31... Bg7: My bishop comes back. Fritz gives black as plus 3.
moves.32. exf5: Fritz prefers taking with the queen, but either way, black as a strong attack.
moves.32... Bd5+: Fritz gives this a plus 7 to black now.
moves.36... Qg2#: And now mate. Many thanks for reading. Please leave a comment or two and rate this on the star system. Until next time dear reader!

players: Steve Lloyd (ECF140) vs. Charles L Higgie (ECF173)
